talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts . How does the minister respond to the report in the Weekend Australian which cited `a highly placed government source' as saying that the 16 federation fund projects elevated by ministers, notwithstanding their below 15 point score, were `weak', and that the ministers had known they were weak but that their selection was `electorally motivated'?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I respond in the way that I think anyone in Australia would respond—that is, we were given authority to make decisions, not simply to rubber stamp departmental recommendations. We did that having considered all of the projects before us, and there were, of course, some hundreds. Whoever that unnamed person was, they obviously do not have the courage of their convictions to go public so I do not know what weight we should attach to those comments. But, certainly, the government vigorously rejects the view. All of the successful projects were highly worthwhile. Indeed, one of the points that seemed to be made in that article is that, because a number of them had not yet got under way in terms of construction, somehow that was a reflection on the quality of the projects selected. That is clearly nonsense. The only other thing I would say is that the article is inaccurate in suggesting that there was a minute from my department warning against elevating low scorers. The minute did not do that; it simply explained the processes used in assessing and ranking applications. I think that Senator Faulkner is basically going through the motions on this one. It must be at least the fifth time that he has run this question. We had about a whole week in the Senate and you had pretty much a nil return from that one. This may be catch-up coverage from News Ltd but, beyond that, I do not think anyone else takes this as a serious policy issue and I suggest that Senator Faulkner should not either.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that some of the 16 projects that the ministers elevated scored as low as eight points out of the 24 in the departmental assessments?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Once again we have Senator Faulkner endeavouring, one way or another, to try to put numbers on projects or to identify and single out projects that might or might not have been approved. The fact of the matter is that he, as he well knows, has now had 12 months to point to any of these projects that he says do not deserve to have been supported. They are all out there; we all know which ones were successful. Senator Faulkner could have spent some time traipsing around to look at these projects. He chose not to do so.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. With respect, the question that I asked Senator Alston is a pretty simple one; it is an important one. I have asked if it is true that some of the 16 projects that were elevated by Senator Alston and Senator Hill scored as low as eight points. That is the question I asked Senator Alston, and I wonder if you might consider directing him to answer that very clear and specific question.
—Senator Faulkner, there is no point of order.
—That was indeed the question, and that is why I answered it, Madam President.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer the minister to the recent public offer of Telstra 2 shares following on from the first sale of Telstra shares, in which a record number of Australians invested. What has been the response of the Australian public to the Telstra 2 public share offer?

—It is no secret that the offer closed last Thursday and that this is the largest single share offer in Australia's history. More than 1.5 million people have taken advantage of becoming new shareholders or of increasing their stake in one of Australia's largest and most dynamic companies. This figure includes approximately half a million people who were not existing Telstra shareholders. It fits neatly with this government's policy that there is a dream not only to own your own home but also that ordinary men and women of Australia will become shareholders. This is great evidence of what privatising Telstra can do in bringing normal Australians into owning shares.

answer.para: As well as that, since this offer was launched last month the government has announced tax reforms, which is good news for tax investors. Under these changes, individuals who hold Telstra shares for more than 12 months will pay capital gains tax on only 50 per cent of their capital gain, and this is good news for those average Australians—normal Australians—who have bought shares in Telstra.

There are also additional tax benefits which come on top of specific measures designed to make Telstra shares more attractive for retail investors. These measures include discounting the share price by at least 40c per share for those who hold on to their shares for more than a year. We have agreed to allow shares to be paid for in two instalments: the first instalment being $4.50 and the balance being paid thereafter. Further benefits accrue to complying superannuation funds. Under the proposed tax changes, these funds would pay no more than 10 per cent on nominal capital gains on assets held for more than one year. Given the specific benefits of the T2 sale, combined with the Ralph taxation plan, it is no wonder that this second tranche has been so successful. I have mentioned that this is great news for normal Australians, average Australians, but it is also good news for retail—

talk.start.para: —Normal?

—They are normal—like you and me, Senator Forshaw. We have never made any secret of our desire to privatise Telstra. What we have done in relation to Telstra has been fully transparent and has been laid out before the public. That has been supported by virtue of the number of people who have taken up these shares. I think it is interesting to look back to Cheryl Kernot, who was previously the Leader of the Democrats. On 22 February 1996 she said that Labor's promise not to privatise Telstra was insincere. She said, `I think Labor in opposition won't sell Telstra, but I am more worried about Labor in government.' That speaks volumes. I can assure the member for Dickson that many people are worried about Labor being in government, and it is not just about what they would not do with Telstra. This has been a great development for Australia, and a great development for average Australians, who have had a great opportunity to invest in such a great company.

subdebateinfo.title: Federal Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer the minister to his statement earlier in question time in relation to certain FCHP projects on which work has not yet commenced. Is it true these include the oil and gas museum at Roma, the cultural and heritage centre at Gilgandra, and the restoration of the Devonport town hall and courthouse? Can the minister explain why it was necessary to rush through the assessment process for these projects in order to have them approved prior to the last federal election, when more than a year later work has not commenced on them?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —As I said, I saw that suggestion in the article. I have not checked it out. I have no idea whether work has commenced on those or some other or all of the other projects.
—You've got no idea?

—I do not, actually. I have no idea about whether work has commenced on these projects, but that has nothing at all to do with the announcement of those projects. In other words, we took the view that these were projects worthy of support. We did not do it on the basis that they would be able to commence the work within a certain period of time. We assume that once the announcement is made people will start to put in place the necessary steps to facilitate that, but they are not matters over which the government would have control. Certainly, there should not be any impediment at our level to enabling those projects to proceed. I simply say again that the project announcements were made on the merits. There was no condition attached that they be commenced within a certain period of time. The assumption would always be that they would commence as soon as feasible, and I assume that that is the case.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the minister can provide some advice to the Senate in relation to the specific questions I asked. Can the minister confirm that the Tasmanian School of Fine Furniture Projects in Launceston did not meet the minimum funding criterion of $500,000 yet was promoted by the former member for Bass and elevated by the minister and his colleague Senator Hill against the advice of their departments? If so, can he explain why he and Senator Hill chose to ignore the advice of their departments on this and a range of other projects?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —This is a broken record. I do not know how many times we have canvassed this ground. Quite clearly it is a classic example of not wanting to know the facts. Senator Faulkner must have been told at least a dozen times that we were not given advice by our departments—we were simply given a points rating. It was one of the inputs which we took into account. We had the Centenary of Federation's advice on these matters.
—You front up with the information under FOI.
—Order!

—If Senator Faulkner is seriously asking my advice about how the Senate should approach these matters, my advice would be that if you want to know what projects have been commenced and what has happened, then do a bit of footslogging. Get out there and have a good look around. Take your camera with you so you will be able to make a check. Maybe you will be able to tell the difference between announcement and completion and construction, but somehow I doubt it.
—Come clean! Come clean!
—Order! Senator Faulkner, cease shouting during the answer to the question.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. During Senator Alston's answer, on three or four occasions you called Senator Faulkner to order and on each occasion he quite explicitly ignored what you had to say. In the same vein that Senator Knowles and I have raised this matter in the past, I raise a point of order under 203(e). Senator Faulkner is a serial wrecker of order in this place. He persistently and regularly ignores what you have to say and sooner or later he has to be dealt with.

—On the point of order, Madam President: you will be aware that Senator Alston, in breach of the standing orders, was directly addressing me across the chamber. I suggested, by way of interjection, that he come clean on this issue, front up with the FOIs and actually tell the Australian people about the 16 projects he is covering up on. That is reasonable in the circumstances where a minister is directly addressing me across the chamber in the way Senator Alston was doing.

—Senator Faulkner, that is addressing a different issue to the point of order which has been raised and is out of order as a contribution at this time. I did note your frequent interjecting during the answer.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware of the recently released report by the Commonwealth Ombudsman which found, among other things, that Centrelink does not provide enough information to people about their entitlements and that existing law prevents adequate back payments being made to welfare recipients in the event of mistakes being made? In particular, I draw the minister's attention to a quote by the Ombudsman, Mr Ron McLeod, where he says:

question.para: . . . there is a need to achieve a better balance between the risks and responsibilities taken by the service delivery agency compared with those taken by its customers.

Given the government's apparent desire to increase the obligations and requirements put on welfare recipients as part of the principle of mutual obligation, what is the minister going to do to ensure that government agencies and departments meet their obligations to the public?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am aware of some Ombudsman's reports that came out last week, and I suggest that there is much more to the Ombudsman's reports than is able to be encompassed in the senator's question. In fact, the Ombudsman, Mr McLeod, did recognise and acknowledge that some of the failures of the system when it was the old Department of Social Security have now been substantially addressed since the formation of Centrelink. He also acknowledged the new initiatives, which are only of the last few months duration, of having one main contact between people who come to Centrelink for assistance and a staff officer who remains dedicated to that particular person into the future, together with the new concept of dealing with people on a life events model. We do not expect people to know the intricacies of the social security legislation—it is beyond the powers of most senators to get on top of a lot of the arcane delights of that legislation—and we should not be expecting people, often in distress, to come in knowing what their entitlements are.

answer.para: As a result of that thinking, Centrelink and the government have been introducing these new ways of trying to help people. They come and tell us what their issue is, what the problem is—there has been a death in the family, they have had a baby, they have separated or whatever the situation is—and then the person who is scheduled to be their one main contact can help them to see what their entitlements are. I am sure you would agree that they are important initiatives and they make a big difference to people who come for help. The Ombudsman made it clear that he recognised that the introduction of Centrelink had made a considerable improvement to the issues he had been raising, some of which were historical. I am not suggesting that any organisation cannot be improved, but I think we have already made substantial strides in the direction in which reform has to go, which the Ombudsman has identified and recognised.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I certainly acknowledge the Ombudsman's own acknowledgment of some of the improvements in the performance of Centrelink. Nonetheless, the Ombudsman has stated that there is an imbalance in the responsibilities of the service delivery agency compared with those taken by the customers. Does the minister accept that the principle of mutual obligation does not just extend to welfare recipients but extends just as strongly to the government and government agencies in terms of the support and assistance they provide to income support recipients? Will the minister ensure that the imbalance in that obligation that has been identified by the Ombudsman gets just as much attention as any extra obligations that the government may be considering putting on welfare recipients?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I think I have always made it very clear that mutual obligation by its very definition is a two-way street. There is no suggestion that the government does not see obligations on it as well as obligations on people who come to the government for support from the taxpayer. Having said that, I also want to point out to the Senate two things that were very significant in setting up Centrelink. One is that a customer charter was introduced, which Centrelink measures its performance by, and so can everybody else. The second is that the whole focus of the organisation has been on customer service. The measures that I mentioned in my earlier answer are very much part of that focus by the whole organisation—all the people who work in it as well as the government—on providing better customer service. That is what we want to achieve. We may not have reached the optimum yet, but we are certainly improving on the past.

—My question is to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. I refer to media treatment of the republican debate. When Lachlan Murdoch phoned the Prime Minister a couple of weeks ago, as reported in the Financial Review on 7 October, did the Prime Minister complain about the coverage News Ltd newspapers were giving to the republican debate? Did he ask Mr Murdoch to tone down the pro-republican sentiments expressed in the News Ltd controlled media, or did he ask him to give Kerry Jones, Senator Minchin and other monarchists more space?
—I obviously was not a party to any such discussions, and therefore I do not know.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to find that out and, while he is finding that out, didn't the Prime Minister signal at the Constitutional Convention that, as Prime Minister, he would remain neutral during the debate? If so, why is he deliberately running interference with media organisations in regard to their coverage of the referendum debate?

—Madam President, I don't think the Prime Minister is neutral; he is a monarchist. He is actually more of a monarchist than some others who are relying on what they claim to be deficiencies in the other side's argument. But I cannot imagine the Prime Minister interfering in media coverage in the way that has been suggested by the honourable senator. In such circumstances I do not really think it is worth worrying him with the matter.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable and Non-profit Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is he aware of the front-page story in today's Age whereby the Democrats are calling for exemption from the GST for charities and non-profit organisations? I ask the minister: is it not a fact that the Democrats were the single agent responsible for the GST being placed on charities and non-profit organisations—actually, the glue that made that tax stick? How much will be raised through the GST from the non-profit sector in Australia in taxes? What will be the compliance costs for charitable organisations and non-profit organisations, including sporting organisations, right across the country? Will non-profit organisations be given tax concessions to make up for these compliance costs that, as has been indicated, will be going to profitable organisations?

—I thank Senator Brown for that question. Senator Brown, we had a very long debate on tax reform in this chamber. Some people went missing in action; others decided to play a very constructive role in that debate. If I may name the groups that went missing in action: the Labor Party were clearly one group that had a chance to make a contribution to debate on tax reform but, unfortunately, went missing, made no contribution at all, and I think they have been widely condemned for it. Another group which I think went missing in action were the Greens, actually, Senator Brown. I think that when you were two—now you are one—the contribution that you and your colleague made to tax reform was quite worthless. I may be wrong, but I can barely remember one constructive comment you made on the whole issue of tax reform.

—On a point of order, Madam President: half the minister's time has gone but he has not addressed three specific questions I asked about the money to be raised from non-profit organisations through the GST and what reparations will be made. I hope that the minister will get to the substantial questions before time has elapsed.
—You are entitled to hope that, Senator.

—He asked me about the role of the Democrats in tax reform, and I am coming to that, Senator, if you will bear with me. Then of course there was another group that decided to play a constructive role in tax reform, and that was the Democrats. They had particular views in this area. They were views which in some areas overlapped ours but in other areas differed. There were, as you will be aware, Senator, very constructive discussions and negotiations with the Democrats, and ultimately the tax reform package passed through.There was one party that went to an election with a very similar policy to ours in relation to FBT issues on charities, and that was the Labor Party. I am sure if I am wrong Senator Cook will jump to his feet. Can I say on that particular issue that the Labor Party, if I recall correctly, were quite specific.

answer.para: I am well aware there has been a prolonged debate on this. My colleagues and I have spoken to many charitable bodies. We have received submissions from various charitable bodies. I read on the front page of the Age that Senator Murray made some comments on this particular issue, but I think the government's position on this is well-known and I do not propose to make any further comments today.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: in view of the fact that he has essentially agreed that the Democrats have been part of imposing the GST on every charity, every sporting organisation and every non-profit organisation in Australia, how much—in terms of hundreds of millions of dollars—will be taken off charities in this country through the GST as applied by the Democrats, and have they made any approach at all to the government, now recognising the damage they are doing to charities, to try to ameliorate that damage which the GST will cause—which the Democrats have caused? Can the minister give any detail of any significant approach that has been made at all, or has no approach really been made?

—Senator Brown, you would be the last person I would tell about any approach from any person, to be quite frank, because you have a magnificent record of being absolutely impossible to negotiate with on any major issue.
—Senator Kemp, your remarks should be directed through the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. I have to tell you, Senator Brown, that I will not be providing any indication to you about any discussions which may or may not have been had. What I suggest you do in relation to charities—
—Senator, direct your remarks through the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. Why don't you have a good read and you will see that the non-commercial activities of charities are GST free. You would learn that charities in many ways will benefit very substantially from the tax reform package. So, Madam President, I think Senator Brown—rather than trying to score cheap political points—for a change should get down—(Time expired)

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Vietnamese National Assembly Council for Ethnic Minorities led by the Chairman, Mr Cu Hoa Van. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Does the Prime Minister stand by his decision to direct Minister Vanstone to withdraw from a public debate on the Republic Referendum with Minister Minchin? Why then has the Prime Minister not disciplined his closest ally on the monarchy, Senator Minchin, for his blatant misrepresentation and distortion of comments by the Treasurer while Mr Costello was not even in the country to defend himself? Does the Prime Minister's supposed neutral stance only operate when republican ministers join the public debate and disappear when the royalist Minister Minchin engages in dirty tricks against his ministerial colleagues?
—Senator Cook, I would ask you to withdraw the epithet. I think it is contrary to the standing orders.
—Madam President, I am not sure what you are referring to, but if I have offended the standing orders I withdraw the relevant remarks.

—These are indeed strange questions because one normally thinks of question time as an opportunity for the opposition to try to win points against the government. The situation in this instance is that the government does not hold a position in relation to this referendum other than on matters of process. Liberals are entitled to vote in the way that they choose. Some will vote for retention of the existing system and some will vote for change. On the Liberal side, that is something that we are proud of. We are not going to be embarrassed by the fact that we are not subject to the whip, that we are allowed to hold different points of view on important national issues like this. What a stark contrast with the Labor Party. They would be whipped out of the Labor Party, expelled, if they dared to take a different point of view. How could the fact of senators on the other side trying to demonstrate that there are different points of view within the Liberal Party win them a political point? I would have thought most Australians would think that this is the sort of issue upon which parliamentarians should be able to make an individual choice. We are pleased that we are able to do that.

answer.para: In relation to process, yes, the Prime Minister has given Australia, through his support of this process, the opportunity to make this choice for the future: either move to a new system or retain the existing system. As a republican, I am pleased that he has been prepared to do so. Australians, because of Mr Howard, will have an opportunity to make a choice. Australians who are members of the Liberal Party will choose according to what they think is in the best interests of the Australian people, not what their party tells them to do.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators should not be speaking to each other across the chamber.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know what question the minister was answering but it was not the question I asked him, which was: why then has the Prime Minister not disciplined Senator Minchin for his blatant misrepresentation and distortion of comments by the Treasurer? Does the Prime Minister's neutral stance operate only for republicans and not for royalists? While he might direct his attention to answering the questions I actually asked rather than make a speech, can he also answer this question. In the Australian on 7 October, it was reported:

question.para: Nick Minchin has split the coalition over the republican referendum, accusing his colleague Peter Costello of hypocrisy over the proposed republican model and threatening an outbreak of inter-government fighting.
Can the minister confirm that to be?

talk.start.para: —What a sorry opposition. I guess there is not much for them to raise. This government has got the economy right. It has taken the hard decisions and it has got the taxation system right. It has got social security right. It is doing such a good job that all the opposition can do is try to create divisions within the government on the republican referendum. What they have not yet woken up to is the fact that we accept divisions on our side. We are proud of it. We are allowed to have different points of view and a different perspective. My advice to the opposition is that they should search a little harder for something that is relevant to their responsibility as an alternative government. When they do that, when they start working up some policies and presenting an alternative on the big issues that are facing this nation, then they might be treated as credible by the Australian people and do something that is worthwhile.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Will the minister inform the Senate of recent labour force figures and what further employment initiatives the government will be introducing to create more real jobs and raise the living standards of all Australians? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy approach and what would be the impact if these were to be implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is very encouraging when we look at the labour force figures. It is no easy task in the face of dedicated and persistent opposition from a major political party in this country. Nonetheless, the unemployment rate remains steady at 7.2 per cent. That is the lowest rate since August 1990. We all remember who was in government then and how much effort they made to do anything about it. Of course they were not interested in flexing up the labour market or making any of the necessary changes that we have been pursuing. The important aspect of the September labour force data is the continuing rise in employment, with most of the new jobs in full-time employment. There have been more than 500,000 new jobs created since the coalition came into office. In conjunction with that, the participation rate also continues to rise. As we know, that simply makes it more difficult to hold the unemployment rate steady, let alone have it going south. All of those indicators are favourable. They come about as a result of hard work and we are determined to keep going on this front.

answer.para: Certainly unfair dismissal laws are universally recognised in the community by everyone except the ACTU and their parliamentary acolytes as a very important inhibitor to employment growth in the small business sector. Nonetheless, the Labor Party continues to vigorously oppose those because they might somehow threaten the very healthy incomes that a lot of industrial advocates earn, obviously because the union movement simply does not like anything that flexes up the small business sector. Secret ballots and the next round of industrial relations changes are also very important. We know they will be opposed tooth and nail.

Probably the most disappointing thing of all is to find that Cheryl Kernot is now being given responsibility for looking after the employment sector. If she was paralysed and could not move out of her marginal seat of Dickson, which has one of the lowest unemployment rates of any electorate, what is she going to do about regional unemployment? Does that mean she simply will not be able to go to those areas—no go? Presumably she will make virtual appearances. She will get herself onto the Internet. She will be out there videoconferencing her head off. Quite clearly, we cannot expect any increase in quality from that front. All I can say is that her employment policy is very focused. It is simply designed to ensure that she wins a marginal seat.

That is not what the people of Australia expect. They want someone out there looking after ordinary families. They want them to address the issues of employment and job creation. As Senator Hill pointed out, we have the Job Network. Long-term unemployment is coming down. These things come about because of policy changes.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Do people like Senator Faulkner want to make a real contribution? After all, he was the one that put the coffee pot on. It has certainly gone off the boil in recent times, but he can claim a large share of the credit for Ms Kernot now having this poisoned chalice. He ought to come to her defence. We think it is very unfair that Senator Faulkner is not prepared to come to her assistance. If you cannot write some policy work for her, at least get the Queensland right wing off her back. We all know this is about Kevin Rudd getting on the front bench at her expense.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, get out there. Do something. You said she would fit very well into the Labor Party because she was a classic mainstream Left thinker. That is not a problem. The problem is that you should get on your bike and get out to the other electorates. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Car Industry

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Minchin, Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Is the minister aware of reports that the senior executives of Australia's four car companies will meet next week to frame a strategy to prevent plant shutdowns and redundancies in the lead-up to the introduction of the GST? Is the minister aware that one senior executive was reported as saying:

question.para: . . . unless the Government is prepared to act, we are looking down the barrel of plant closures—at least at Ford, Toyota and Mitsubishi.
Does the minister agree with this assessment?

talk.start.para: —This is a rather remarkable question coming from the ALP, which advocates high prices for cars. This is the party that wants to retain a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on motor vehicles and therefore a high price for cars. We are the party that is advocating a lower price for new cars for ordinary Australians, by introducing a 10 per cent GST which will have a significant effect on reducing the price of new cars. So it is a pretty silly question coming from the ALP, which defends Australians having to pay more tax on their cars than they will under our government as of 1 July next year.

answer.para: The facts relating to car sales are that 807,000 cars were sold last year—the most cars ever sold in this country. That was a record year last year following another record in 1997. We have had two record years in a row. After such an incredible sales pattern in 1998, sales have fallen back marginally this year. In year to September sales so far, for three-quarters of this year, sales are down 2.9 per cent from the same period in 1998. We are down 2.9 per cent—not a great fall, but certainly it has come off from that record year. But sales this year are still 11 per cent higher than they were at the same time in 1997, which was, of itself, then a record year for car sales. Relatively speaking, the market is still doing fairly well. Locally manufactured vehicles have a greater share of the market now than they did last year—48 per cent compared with 45 per cent. We are monitoring car sales closely. We do not want to see the industry suffer. This tax change is good for the car industry. But we have said that in relation to transitional matters we will monitor sales closely. We are talking with the industry on a regular basis and we have not ruled out action if it is absolutely necessary. But on the figures so far we do not see that action of that kind is necessary.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, given that Ford has already stood down 3,500 workers and is reportedly planning further stand-downs in the next three weeks, sales of passenger vehicles slumped by 9.7 per cent last month—the fifth consecutive monthly decline—and new vehicle registrations are at their lowest level since September 1997, what more evidence do you need before this government will act?

—I really do not have much to add. I have already told the senator that car sales have fallen off slightly from 1998 but there is no evidence yet that the fall-off from the record 1998 year is induced by any expectation on the part of purchasers that cars will be cheaper. Of course, while cars will be a lot cheaper for new car buyers, I would say that buyers do need to take account of the changeover price. I certainly would encourage buyers to stay in the market and keep buying new cars. Cars are a very good buy at the moment in terms of the quality of the Australian product and the prices they are being offered at. Sales are 11 per cent ahead of what was then a record year in 1997. That is staggering. We are talking about a massive reduction in the price of new vehicles as of 1 July 2000. This is one of the best things that could happen to the car industry. The car industry strongly supported the GST. It will mean a big reduction in prices and a big boost to the exports of the car industry.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Alston. Is the minister aware of the media release by Minister Warren Truss dated 28 September 1999 about the dairy industry restructure package? Is the minister concerned about this statement in the media release:

question.para: The package will be funded through a levy of 11 cents on all retail milk sales. This levy is unlikely to have any impact on retail prices as farm gate prices are expected to fall after deregulation by at least this amount.
Does this mean that farmers will pay for their own restructure package themselves?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The package that the government announced did respond to the dairy industry's request for an adjustment package to manage the impact of deregulation and the transition to an open market. The government is not driving deregulation, and the package will only be available in the event that the states proceed with deregulation of their market milk arrangements. Quite clearly, it is in the long-term interests of consumers that a structure be put in place that enables permanently lower milk prices to become available. Under the package, dairy farmers would receive structural adjustment payments to enable them—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—I presume Senator Woodley does not advocate a cold shower approach and does not say that there should be no structural adjustment assistance. Presumably, he is on the side of consumers, so therefore we can assume that he broadly supports the notion of structural adjustment payments being made to enable those dairy farmers to improve their efficiency, competitiveness and profits after deregulation. Alternatively, for those for whom selling the farm is appropriate, an exit payment subject to an assets test will be available. It has been made perfectly clear by the minister that the package will be funded through a levy on drinking milk sales. It is not anticipated that milk prices will be adversely affected. There will shortly be a meeting with state and territory agricultural ministers to discuss dairy industry deregulation and structural adjustment assistance. We are confident that this package will be in the interests of all concerned. It is not meant to be a special deal for farmers; it is meant to be very much something that consumers will benefit from.
—How?

—By lower prices. It is quite simple. I know you blokes do not believe in it. If it is not in the riding instructions from the ACTU, you will not have a bar of it. But we actually do put the long-term interests of consumers first, and we certainly do in this instance. We believe that this approach will be the one that will best deliver the goods.

—I thank the minister for his answer, but he got it wrong—so I will try again with a supplementary question. I ask the minister: doesn't the fact that there will be a drop in the farm gate price mean that the dairy industry will borrow the money to compensate farmers at commercial rates, farmers will lose at least 11c per litre on the current farm gate price, this loss will cover the cost of repaying the borrowings and farmers will pay tax on any compensation that they receive? Minister, is this a great restructure package or a great confidence trick?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The short answer is that it is the former and not the latter. There will be significant reductions at the farm gate, and that is why it is important to have a structural adjustment package available. But in the longer term, after you have had that transitional phase, lower prices will be paid by consumers. That will mean lower amounts in the pockets of the dairy farmers, and that is why they will have to make a decision in that intervening period about whether to exit the industry or to take the adjustment proceeds and restructure their businesses. All of that is very much in the interests of an efficient market. It is in the interest of consumers. The borrowing, compensation for losses and everything else that flows from that package will be commercial arrangements that farmers will enter into. Presumably, if they think that it makes sense to borrow, then they will borrow. If they think it makes sense to get out, they will get out. We are not telling them how to conduct their future operations. We are giving them the flexibility and the transitional financial assistance to do it.

Senator Calvert would be interested to know that one of those funding successes in recent times was for a project in Tasmania in the Derwent Valley. answer.para: In addition to the Rural Plan, we have a number of other recent initiatives, including further funding for Networking the Nation and our Rural Transaction Centre program. What passes for policy from the ALP is the spokesman in this chamber getting up and being personally abusive to me and to other members here. The former spokesperson, Ms Kernot, said that she had a lot of policy proposals on the go. She said she was handing over a substantial number of policy ideas to the new shadow minister, Mr Martin Ferguson. It is a pity she did not let the public know about those before she asked for a change from that portfolio. Perhaps I should not say she asked for a change. That is what she initially said and that is what Mr Beazley said, but then in the Courier-Mail on Friday she said that she did not ask for the change. When Mr Beazley was told about that, he said that Ms Kernot had suffered a recollection problem. I suggest to Ms Kernot that she see Dr Lawrence to get some counselling on that particular matter. subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the distribution of funds for the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects program.

We have the situation now where, in question time in the Senate today, Senator Alston was unable to respond on behalf of the government to a report that appeared in the Weekend Australian . That report cited a highly placed government source who indicated that the 16 Federation Fund projects that did not reach the government's own minimum 15-point score were weak, that the ministers knew they were weak and that their selection as projects was electorally motivated.

Senator Alston could not respond on that issue. He could not tell us how many of the 16 projects that he and Senator Hill pulled out of their bottom drawer scored as low as eight points out of 24 in the departmental assessment. Even though they were rushed through and approved for announcement in the last election campaign a year ago, he could not tell us why it was necessary for that quick assessment process and those public announcements when work has not yet commenced on the projects themselves. Of course, he could not tell us whether the Tasmanian School of Fine Furniture project in Launceston met the minimum funding criteria of $500,000 or whether that was another one of the projects that he and Senator Hill pulled out of the bottom drawer.

That is the problem we have here. We have a massive cover-up from Senator Alston and Senator Hill and their departments on this issue. We have been able to extract information that there were 16 projects that did not meet the department's minimum 15-point threshold, but the ministers will not identify them. They will not tell us the cost of the projects. They will not tell us how many of these projects were recommended by the National Council for the Centenary of Federation. They cover up the identities of these 16 projects, they use every trick in the book, they run thick black texta lines over their statements of reasons and they defy the Auditor-General's guidelines.

Eventually we will get to the bottom of this. Eventually we will extract the identity of these 16 projects. We will find out which ones they were. When we know the identity of all of the 16 projects that these ministers found in a bottom drawer, we are going to run the ruler over them. We are going to find where they are, we are going to look at their electoral significance, we are going to look at when those particular projects were announced and we are going to compare them with the other 70 approved choices that were ignored by the ministers. We are also going to look at the nine projects ranked very high—between 19 and 24 points on the criteria points list—but which went unfunded. We are going to run a ruler over them as well. We are really going to try to make sure that these ministers are held accountable. They have used every dirty trick in the book to try to cover this matter up. They have run on this, but they cannot hide.

These ministers have been caught red-handed funding projects in marginal electorates with millions of dollars of taxpayers' money and on the eve of an election campaign. These projects were announced during an election campaign for party political purposes. I can assure the Senate that, if that is the case, and if that case is proven, we will be demanding the resignation of the responsible ministers. We will get to the bottom of this, we will keep asking the embarrassing questions and we will keep this government and these ministers accountable on these issues. We will continue to scrutinise this massive Federation Fund fiddle. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Isn't it really sad that the ALP cannot come up with any new material? It is like listening to a cracked record that keeps running around in the same track as poor old Senator Faulkner tries to get a few political points out of this issue. It is an issue which was covered extensively and comprehensively about a month ago. The ALP found then that there was no gold to be dug out, and yet they persist. Here they are again today. We have all been away for a week, yet the best they can come up with is to re-run this old issue, this old material, which has been thoroughly dealt with and from which there is no political gain for the ALP.

speech.para: More than anything else it shows how bereft the ALP are of policy ideas. They have so little to offer the Australian public that they have to go back to an issue which they have found before was a bare cupboard for them. I suppose it is indicative of the quality of Senator Faulkner's leadership that he cannot come up with a new issue to pursue the government on. The fact of the matter is that all of these Federation Fund projects were aboveboard and quite legitimate. All of the projects were ruled eligible.

talk.start.para: —Sixteen of them failed.

—All of them met the criteria; there were no projects that failed at all. The fact of the matter is that the government had a certain amount of discre tion in deciding which projects should be funded, and the government quite legitimately used its discretion in deciding which other projects would be funded.

speech.para: Another point which was made in the last round of discussions on this, but which has not been made this time, was to allege that the caretaker convention was breached in deciding which projects would be approved. I suppose that one of the other speakers will raise this issue this afternoon. But, of course, the caretaker convention was not breached. The normal procedures were followed. The approval for funding of these projects was given before the election was called, and there is no prohibition on the announcement of projects during an election period in situations where decisions have already been taken. I say that in anticipation; I am sure that one of the speakers from the opposition will raise that issue, and it may as well be dealt with before it is raised.

There have been claims of bias in the distribution of grants, but let us look at that. Those claims of bias are wrong. Of the 16 successful projects, 38, or 64 per cent, were located in 62 per cent of electorates held by the coalition, which is fair enough. Eighteen, or 30 per cent, were in the 33 per cent of electorates held by Labor. That is a very even and reasonable distribution of grants. Five per cent of projects were in the five per cent of seats held by Independents, and one project went across multiple electorates. The $70 million Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program represents the largest boost ever provided by the Commonwealth government to these types of projects.

talk.start.para: —One of the biggest pork barrels in a while.
—Talking of pork barrels, I suppose one has to look back at Minister Kelly and the whiteboard. There was certainly no whiteboard and nobody operating like Minister Kelly did a few years ago.

speech.para: The whole history of the Federation Fund has been aboveboard. As I have said, since the ALP have been through this issue before and come up with nothing, it demonstrates how bereft they are of policies and ideas. One must say that the government are not at all ashamed of anything to do with this matter. The government are very proud of what they have done in protecting and preserving Australia's culture and heritage and are very pleased with their achievements. One might ask whether the ALP oppose, for example, the Commonwealth supporting these projects around the country. We are very proud of what we have done. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Senate today is discussing answers to questions from Senator Faulkner to Senator Alston concerning the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program. The Senate is reminded today, by the exchange that occurred, just how weak the government is on this issue. `Weak' is a term that comes up quite frequently in the description of these events. In an article that appeared in the Weekend Australian last weekend, a senior government source claimed that 16 projects which were hand-picked by the government—
—Who is the senior government source?

—Perhaps you could advise us, Senator Hill, who this senior government source is. The senior government source has blown the gaff on you. You have been exposed as participating in what is quite clearly a rorted program, to the extent that the 16 projects which were hand-picked by Senator Hill and Senator Alston were described as being `weak'. They were described as `being electorally motivated' and designed to shore up the government, which was at the time threatened in a number of seats by various political forces, including One Nation, and in Tasmania by other groups.

speech.para: What we have seen exposed in this article is that on 30 August 1998 the Prime Minister flew down to Canberra—he does not live here, so he has to fly in quite a lot. He stopped off on the way to Yarralumla; he travelled down Adelaide Avenue and dropped in to the Lodge to sign a couple of letters. He had 70 million reasons to delay his appointment with the Governor-General which was scheduled for 9 o'clock that day. The 70 million reasons related to the amounts of money that were involved in the letters that he was signing off on that day, which were letters congratulating—this is the irony here—Senator Alston and Senator Hill `for their timely and effective management of the selection process' for these various schemes under this program.

What has been revealed since that time is that the government, under the leadership of Senator Hill and Senator Alston, removed nine projects from the list provided by the departments of projects which had been identified as being above the 15-point threshold or benchmark. A submission issued to the ministers on 20 August highlighted that `the purpose of the submission was to provide them with a list of highly rated projects from which to select various projects' which met the criteria established by the guidelines operating for this program. What replaced these nine projects were 16 projects which were not recommended by the departments and which met entirely different criteria. They were criteria one would expect from Senator Alston, who was at that time the campaign director for the Liberal Party of Victoria and had a very keen eye on the electoral implications of these projects.
Today we have discovered that, one year later, many of these projects have yet to commence construction.

talk.start.para: —The 16 projects.

—Most of those 16 projects have yet to get off the ground. We are told by Senator Alston that it was not a condition of the projects when projects should commence their construction phases. But in a memorandum sent to Senator Alston by the head of the arts section, Mr Les Neilson, he indicated that the projects scoring 15 points out of the possible 24 points did not compare well in terms of their significance or their community benefit to the highest ranked projects, or answer concerns about the ability of the organisation to deliver the project on time and within budget or on the ongoing viability problems. So quite clearly well before these decisions were made, well before the Prime Minister signed off on these letters in defiance of the caretaker conventions of this parliament, the ministers were advised what the likely outcomes would be.

speech.para: Their intentions had nothing to do with consideration of these projects on their merits but had everything to do with consideration of these projects on the basis of the political advantage that would accrue to the government. Their time frames in that regard ended at the time of the election. They were not concerned about the implications that these projects would have in terms of meeting the budgetary considerations or in terms of the quality of the projects concerned. They were all about the election, they were all about winning votes and they were all about establishing a margin of comfort for the government in the election campaign. What would you expect from a minister who was the campaign director for the Liberal Party in Victoria at the time of the election? Foremost in his mind was the issue of winning votes, not undertaking effective administration. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It must have been tough on the opposition side this morning when they were working out what sorts of questions they were going to ask today. If you observed question time, you can just imagine them thinking, `Well, we might ask a few questions on East Timor—but, hang on, we might ask one on that because if we ask any more than that the government might start bringing up what Mr Keating has been saying and what Beazley has been saying, so we will just have a little go at that. Then they would have thought, `We will throw in one about cars and the GST. That is good for a few minutes. We can get a question about that.' So they threw in a couple about cars.

speech.para: That did not seem to get much currency, so, `Here we go, we will go back over the old Federation Fund so-called fiasco.' That has been brought up here so many times. It has been trawled through at estimates. But a journalist down in Tasmania, Bruce Montgomery, who has not featured in the Australian for that long, must have dreamt this story up so that he could get a headline. They saw that and they said, `That is what we are going to do. We will get back on that. We must be getting somewhere.' When you look at what was written in that article, there was nothing new—nothing at all.

I have just heard Senator Carr bringing up the old chestnut of what this Les Neilson was supposed to have said but I think they already know, under the FOI documents that they obtained, that he explained the processes used in assessing and ranking applications but certainly did not warn against elevating those scores. And of course it all goes back to this unnamed person, this senior government source. Well, we would all love to hear who the senior government source is that has made this comment, some 12 months after all this happened—that is the amazing thing.

I believe the only reason questions were asked of Senator Alston today was that those opposite did not have anything else better to talk about. You did not want to talk about the economy because that is going too well for your liking, and you did not want to talk about unemployment, so you have gone back to the old one on federation funding. I wonder what the people of Lyons would say if they thought that Dick Adams was not in favour of the ABT railway. That project has not been started yet, but I do not hear any arguments coming from the opposition over there about why the ABT railway project has not started.

What has happened to the money at York Park? What has happened to the money for the TCA ground? That money was allocated before the election and the fact is that the Launceston City Council, the state government and the crowd up north are trying to put together this package to upgrade York Park oval—and it is the same thing with the TCA ground in Hobart—and it takes time to put these things together. So we have had the situation, just to get a bit of publicity and to try to embarrass the government, of Senator Faulkner coming in here and raking up all this federation funding situation all over again.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —On the women's prison project in Hobart in Duncan Kerr's electorate—a Labor electorate—about $900,000 is going to be spent. That has not started yet. There is no intention of it being started. I have not seen one brick being removed or put back.
—When was it announced?
—I beg your pardon?
—When was it announced?
—I should not respond to these continual interjections, Madam Deputy President.
—You should address the chair and Senator Conroy should, of course, cease interjecting.

—But there were some very fine projects which were put forward in Tasmania. I notice that one that got a mention in the so-called article in the Australian over the weekend was the fine furniture facility in Launceston. That furniture centre of excellence has been around for quite some time: just have a look around this chamber and see some of the furniture that was manufactured by Tasmanian furniture makers who use that facility. That facility has been very good in helping to promote Tasmanian furniture—and of course Tasmanian furniture has been around since Federation—and it is a fine project. In fact the former State President of the Liberal Party, Jim Bowler, headed that area when he was with the Tasmanian development authority or something like that, as I recall. Anyway, when we get down to it, if you look at the distribution of grants, the coalition held 62 per cent of the Commonwealth electorates and the coalition seats received 69 per cent of funds. The Labor Party held 33 per cent—(Time expired)

—It is disappointing sometimes to see the level of preparation that goes into the defence of some of the ministers in this chamber. This, as Senator Calvert and Senator Eggleston have indicated, is an issue that has been around for a while, and you would think that the government could have given its backbench a sufficient level of briefing on this issue so they could put up a competent defence. What they are seeking to hide today is that 16 projects scored below 15 points and some of them obviously scored as low as eight points. When Senator Alston was invited to deny that some projects scored as few as eight points out of 24—

speech.para: Senator Eggleston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Come on, name them.

—Senator Watson, we would like you to name which projects got the eight points. We think that would be in the community interest and in the public interest. What the senators on the other side of this chamber are trying to do is hide from the fact that some projects scored as few as eight points out of 24. When they are asked a question to name them, they do not.

speech.para: Senator Eggleston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Eggleston, you have had your chance to speak.

—What you have to understand in this debate is that 70 projects that scored greater than 15 points were excluded from funding, but 16 that got below the 15 points were included. In fact, nine projects that actually scored the top score possible were excluded. What was wrong with those? That is the question that we put to Senator Alston and that is the question that we put to other senators in this chamber today. What was wrong with the nine projects that got the top score? Why were they dumped? Why did 16 projects get up in this process? Why did some of those projects not score 24, like nine of them? Some of them scored as low as eight. Of the 60 approved projects, only 39 were announced during the election. What a coincidence!

speech.para: No prizes for guessing that all of the projects that were rorted through this process, all of those 16 projects—16 of the 39, nearly 50 per cent of the announcements during the election—were in the government's marginal seats or the seats where they were under pressure from the Labor Party and from One Nation. That is why they will not come clean. That is why they sit here in question time and after question time today refusing to put the facts on the table. Eighty per cent of the 39 that were announced during the election were in coalition seats. What does the department's own advice say to the minister? It says:

Projects scoring below 15 points out of a possible 24 points either did not compare well in terms of significance or community benefit to the highest ranked projects, or, answer concerns about the ability of the organisation to deliver the project on time and within budget and/or had ongoing viability problems.

In other words, those 16 projects that were lifted out of the bottom drawer and were rorted into this program failed the department's criteria on things as fundamental as viability. Surprisingly enough, they were all in your seats—and you wonder why people ask questions.

But what we have seen now is that a government source has stated that Alston and Hill knew these 16 projects were weak at the time they were funded and that their allocation was electorally motivated to shore up threatened government seats where One Nation was strong and in Tasmania where the Liberals were about to be annihilated. And did it do them any good? We have had Senator Calvert already today and it seems we have Senator Watson coming up next. Did this blatant rorting and pork-barrelling do them any good? No, it did not. They do not hold a single lower house seat in Tasmania and they barely hold their Senate seats. That is what has happened. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is an unusual debate today—unusual for three reasons. Firstly, quite a long time has expired since the election when this would have essentially been a hot topic. That is the first reason. One must ask the motivation for raising such an issue at this time.

speech.para: Secondly, the issue has been canvassed perhaps more than most issues in this Senate. We have had motions to take note. This is a re-run. It is a repetition. The opposition has dropped a number of items because they were found to be blatantly wrong, blatantly incorrect. I was quite interested in Senator Carr's contribution. It was a very different contribution today than the one he gave last time. Thankfully, Senator Carr has mended his ways and, obviously corrected, recognised that some of the matters he raised previously were quite incorrect. I think that is perhaps one of the pleasing aspects of this debate.

The third reason I think the debate is most unusual is that it is taking place although this matter has been referred to the Auditor-General, who is currently conducting a preliminary investigation. The Auditor-General has not yet released his report. So the timing is certainly premature. If anything, I suppose it would be somewhat offensive to an Auditor-General to be raising and debating issues when the matters are under his investigation at the present time.

So I have given you three reasons why I think it is inappropriate and out of date to be discussing this particular issue. I think it is very difficult to debate an issue when you are talking about issues—in terms of point scoring, et cetera—that we are unfamiliar with. I ask the Labor Party senators, particularly those from Tasmania, to challenge the amount of money that was given to the electorate of Denison—a Labor electorate, for which Mr Kerr is the member and holds that seat by a very substantial majority. Does he want that money withdrawn? Does he not want that to proceed?

We have the case of Dick Adams who received funding for the majority of the projects in Tasmania—again, a Labor held electorate. I do not hear Dick Adams raising cries of angst and concern about this. I would ask Michelle O'Byrne whether she wants the money withdrawn from the School of Fine Furniture, which was a very strong project. Ask her whether she wishes that or whether it does not have her approval.

We heard that most of the projects had not been proceeded with. The Devonport mayor said that the progress on the city's courthouse and town hall was also on track—again, refuting an allegation that these projects had not started. She said:
We're delighted to get the grant whether it was politically motivated or not.
Obviously she was not too worried. She said:

Neither the Statutory Rules, nor the Explanatory Statement, indicate the basis on which the fees have been set. The Committee would therefore appreciate your advice as to whether that basis is cost recovery, or whether there is some other reason for the particular levels of fees established.

Dear Senator Coonan
Thank you for your letter of 12 August 1999 concerning the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (ARPANS) Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 1) Statutory Rules 1999 No. 97 .

These Regulations establish the application fees for Commonwealth entities applying to the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) for licences under the ARPANS Act (No. 133, 1998) to use nuclear and radiation facilities and sources.
In response to the Committee's query regarding the basis on which the fees have been set, I am able to provide the following information.
The fees described in the ARPANS Amendment Regulations have been set on the basis of recovery of the costs of regulation. The Government decision to establish ARPANSA required that:
. the current funding levels for the former Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL) and Nuclear Safety Bureau (NSB) form the base funding for the new Agency; and

. ARPANSA establish `user pays' initiatives as soon as possible to ensure that the costs associated with implementing ARPANSA's new regulatory responsibilities are borne by the Commonwealth entitles subject to the regulatory controls.

As well as the normal appropriations for the ARL and NSB, the Department of Health and Aged Care and the Department of Industry, Science and Resources provided some additional `start up' funding. The amount of this `start up' funding available in 1999-2000 has been discounted from the level of fees which would otherwise have applied in that year.

In order to identify the necessary level of fees to enable ARPANSA to cost recover in relation to the new regulatory functions, ARPANSA contracted the independent firm of consultants, Ernst and Young. Ernst and Young employed an Activity Based Costing (ABC) methodology to:
. measure the cost of activities, products and services previously undertaken or provided by the ARL and NSB;
. cost all of the additional regulatory activities of ARPANSA; and
. advise on options for cost recovery and for a pricing structure for licence fees.

A schedule of fees for the various installations and sources was developed by ARPANSA following consideration of the Ernest and Young report. In setting the application fees, account was taken of the likely work involved by ARPANSA in assessing the applications (this in turn follows from the hazard of the facility or source) in order that the fees be proportionate to the cost of regulation. A number of other factors were reviewed for comparative purposes, including the level of fees charged under comparable State and Territory regulatory arrangements. It was noted that at the time, there was uncertainty about the numbers of sources that might be involved in some agencies. Consequently, in order to avoid an unreasonable total cost for a regulated entity holding large numbers of similar sources (that is, unreasonable compared with the cost of regulation), some of the fees have a total cap for an organisation.

A draft schedule of fees was circulated to all Commonwealth agencies to be regulated under the ARPANS Act and following extensive consultation with those agencies, the ARPANS Amendment Regulations were prepared.

In order to ensure maximum transparency and accountability in relation to the arrangements for cost recovery, ARPANSA will be implementing an ABC-based cost recovery system to ensure proper recording of the resources devoted to particular clients and to assist in the setting of licence charges for future years. A full account of expenditure in relation to regulation of Commonwealth agencies will be reported by the Chief Executive Officer of ARPANSA in quarterly and annual reports to Parliament. Further, annual auditing will occur in fulfilment of the Agency's obligations under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1998 .
If the Committee has any further queries or wishes to clarify any matters raised in this correspondence, please do not hesitate to contact my office.
Yours sincerely
(Sgd) Dr Michael Wooldridge

These Statutory Rules amend the Principal Regulations in relation to the Christmas Island Fishery, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Fishery and the Macquarie Island Fishery.

One purpose of these Statutory Rules is to set an application fee for entry to the Macquarie Island Fishery. That fee, of $5350, is described in the Explanatory Statement as being `significantly higher than the usual fee' for such an application. The explanation given for this higher fee is merely `the process involved', but the higher fee is also justified on the basis of the costs that the AFMA will incur in that process. There is, however, no indication, in the Explanatory Statement, of the degree to which this fee is higher than others, nor is there any indication of the nature of the process involved in considering applications.
The Committee would appreciate your advice on these matters.
Yours sincerely
Helen Coonan
Senator Helen Coonan
Chair
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Helen

Thank you for your letter of 12 August 1999 seeking clarification on aspects of Fisheries Management Regulation 1999 (Nos. 2 and 3), Statutory Rules 1999 Nos 98 and 130. Your letter raised a number of specific issues on which I have sought advice from the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) in preparing this response.

AFMA advised that its approach reflected advice from the Office of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions that under existing Regulations, AFMA would not have been able to effectively rebut the presumption that the return had been posted. For this reason, the Regulation was amended to require that the return be received by AFMA within ten days of fish being received.

AFMA does not routinely contact fish receivers when returns are due as there are a large number of fish receiver permit holders, and a large number of returns are received. Moreover, returns are due at a time relative to fish being received, which can not be predicted.

However, AFMA now has implemented an administrative system in which twice-monthly checks of computer records pick up the non-receipt of returns. Once this occurs, a letter is sent advising that a return has not been received and requesting that it be forwarded to AFMA within 14 days. A self-addressed envelope is provided. If this deadline is not met, another letter is sent requesting that the return be made within a further seven days.

The majority of returns are received by AFMA on time or after the first letter is sent. When a return has not been received after the second letter, remedial action is considered which may include the issue of a $200 infringement notice or prosecution action. Where a fish receiver comes to AFMA's attention, they can then be monitored on an individual basis to ensure that future returns are received by AFMA within the time limits set by the Regulations.

The requirement that returns be received by AFMA within ten days of fish being received is part of the regulatory scheme designed to ensure that AFMA receives accurate and timely returns about the taking and disposal of fish. Compliance with this requirement is especially important in fisheries managed by AFMA in which total allowable catches are set and operators are only entitled to take limited amounts of certain fish species (known as a quota management system). There is a concern that if returns are not received by AFMA within a short time after fish are received, it may be possible for returns to be falsified to remove information about catch that has been sold on illegal markets, or for other reasons not accounted for.

The Macquarie Island Fishery permit application fee of $5,350 was many times higher than the usual managed fishery permit application fee, which is $170. However, the fee was set in the same way as the lower fee. That is, by applying the government's cost recovery policy to recover costs associated with processing applications.

In most fisheries managed by AFMA, there are more than a hundred operators. In fisheries where applications for fishing permits are made upon expiry of an existing permit, the costs associated with processing applications are not high, often involving little more than the licensing staff time necessary to generate and send a new permit to the applicant.

However, as noted in the Explanatory Statement, access to the Macquarie Island Fishery has been restricted to a single fishing permit holder in light of the sensitivity of the Macquarie Island environment. A detailed policy was developed by AFMA for the Fishery, which provided for a competitive selection process involving evaluation by an expert panel to determine the successful applicant. I am advised by AFMA that this selection has now taken place. This approach was taken in recognition of the high potential economic value of the Macquarie Island Fishery, the high level of interest expressed by the fishing industry, and the remoteness of the fishery (which requires multi-million dollar investment by the successful applicant).

The evaluation panel established to make recommendations concerning the granting of the available permit was highly specialised, some of the members being experts in their field and not AFMA staff. A consultant was employed to support the panel. Naturally there were expenses, such as transport and similar costs, associated with acquiring the services of the panel members and a consultant. A number of AFMA staff members also provided support services to the panel.

The application fee was calculated by estimating these costs and, on the basis of experience in other similar processes, estimating the number of applicants likely to be received. I am advised that AFMA received fewer applications than anticipated and the process has in fact cost AFMA more than was recovered via application fees.
I trust that this information clarifies the situation for the Standing committee.
Yours sincerely
(Sgd) Warren Truss

However, from the explanation given in the Explanatory Statement, it appears that the reduction should be made in any case, in order to ensure the payment of the surcharge deduction amount.
